introparagraph: Experience Sri Lanka's most elusive wildlife in the vast seclusion of Wilpattu National Park. Occupying a vast swathe of land bordering the copper-sand beaches of the north west coast, the ancient ruins of the Cultural Triangle and the Northern Province, this is Sri Lanka's largest and oldest game reserve. Home to myriad endemic species, the park fosters sensational bird life, Asian Elephants, Sri Lankan Leopards, Sri Lankan Sloth Bears.

sub1paragraph: On a Wilpattu safari you have the chance of encountering 31 species of mammals residing within Wilpattu, of which 4 are threatened. These are the Sri Lankan Elephant, Sri Lankan Sloth Bear,
sub1paragraph2: Sri Lankan Leopard and the Water Buffalo. Other animal species that can be seen on safari drives are the Sambar and Spotted Deer, Mongoose, Mouse Deer, and Shrew.

sub2paragraph: Many species of Owl, Tern, Gull, Eagle, Kite and Buzzard along with the Painted Stork, Sri Lankan Junglefowl and the Little Cormorant can be found at the Wilpattu National Park.
sub2paragraph2: Wetland birdlife includes the Garganey, Pintail, Whistling Teal, Spoonbill, White Ibis, Large White Egret, Cattle Egret and Purple Heron.

sub3paragraph: Wilpattu National Park is in the north west of Sri Lanka, around 35km west of Anuradhapura and 32km north of Puttalam. It takes around 90-minutes to reach the reserve from Uga Ulagalla, and is around a 4-hour drive from Uga Residence in Colombo.
sub3paragraph2: From Wilpattu National Park's main entrance at Hunuvilagama, the track weaves through beautiful lowland forest for around 10-kilometres before you reach the more open wildlife areas.
